poem_title: Apollo Outwitted. To the Honourable Mrs. FINCH, under her Name of Ardelia,
author: Jonathan Swift
poem_alt_title: To the Honourable Mrs. FINCH , under her Name of Ardelia ,

lines.line_text: now shortning every Shade,
Up to the Northern  came,
And Thence Beheld a Lovely Maid
Attending on a Royal Dame.

stanzas.stanza_text:
now shortning every Shade,
Up to the Northern  came,
And Thence Beheld a Lovely Maid
Attending on a Royal Dame.

lines.line_text: THE God laid down his Feeble Rays,
Then lighted from his Glitt'ring Coach,
But fenc'd his Head with his own Bays
Before he durst the Nymph approach.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE God laid down his Feeble Rays,
Then lighted from his Glitt'ring Coach,
But fenc'd his Head with his own Bays
Before he durst the Nymph approach.

lines.line_text: UNDER those Sacred Leaves, Secure
From common Lightning of the Skies,
He fondly thought he might endure
The Flashes of  Eyes.

stanzas.stanza_text:
UNDER those Sacred Leaves, Secure
From common Lightning of the Skies,
He fondly thought he might endure
The Flashes of  Eyes.

lines.line_text: THE Nymph who oft had read in Books,
Of that Bright God whom Bards invoke,
Soon knew  by his looks,
And Guest his Business e're he Spoke.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THE Nymph who oft had read in Books,
Of that Bright God whom Bards invoke,
Soon knew  by his looks,
And Guest his Business e're he Spoke.

lines.line_text: HE in the old Celestial Cant,
Confest his Flame, and swore by ,
What e're she would desire, to Grant,
But Wise  knew his Tricks.

stanzas.stanza_text:
HE in the old Celestial Cant,
Confest his Flame, and swore by ,
What e're she would desire, to Grant,
But Wise  knew his Tricks.

lines.line_text: had warn'd her to beware,
Of Stroling God's, whose usual Trade is,
Under pretence of Taking Air,
To pick up Sublunary Ladies.

stanzas.stanza_text:
had warn'd her to beware,
Of Stroling God's, whose usual Trade is,
Under pretence of Taking Air,
To pick up Sublunary Ladies.

lines.line_text: HOWE'ER she gave no flat Denial,
As having Malice in her Heart,
And was resolv'd upon a Tryal,
To Cheat the God in his own Art.

stanzas.stanza_text:
HOWE'ER she gave no flat Denial,
As having Malice in her Heart,
And was resolv'd upon a Tryal,
To Cheat the God in his own Art.

lines.line_text: HEAR my Request the Virgin said
Let which I please of all the Nine
Attend when e'er I want their Aid,
Obey my Call, and only mine.

stanzas.stanza_text:
HEAR my Request the Virgin said
Let which I please of all the Nine
Attend when e'er I want their Aid,
Obey my Call, and only mine.

lines.line_text: BY Vow Oblig'd, By Passion led,
The God could not refuse her Prayer;
He wav'd his Wreath Thrice o'er her Head,
Thrice mutter'd something to the Air.

stanzas.stanza_text:
BY Vow Oblig'd, By Passion led,
The God could not refuse her Prayer;
He wav'd his Wreath Thrice o'er her Head,
Thrice mutter'd something to the Air.

lines.line_text: AND now he thought to Seize his due,
But she the Charm already try'd,
heard the Call
To wait at Bright  Side.

stanzas.stanza_text:
AND now he thought to Seize his due,
But she the Charm already try'd,
heard the Call
To wait at Bright  Side.

lines.line_text: ON sight of this Celestial ,
thought it vain to stay,
Nor in her Presence durst be Rude,
But made his Leg and went away.

stanzas.stanza_text:
ON sight of this Celestial ,
thought it vain to stay,
Nor in her Presence durst be Rude,
But made his Leg and went away.

lines.line_text: HE hop'd to find some lucky Hour,
When on their Queen the Muses wait;
But  owns  Power,
For Vows Divine are kept by Fate.

stanzas.stanza_text:
HE hop'd to find some lucky Hour,
When on their Queen the Muses wait;
But  owns  Power,
For Vows Divine are kept by Fate.

lines.line_text: THEN full of Range  Spoke,
Deceitful Nymph I see thy Art,
And tho' I can't my gift revoke,
I'll disappoint its Nobler Part.

stanzas.stanza_text:
THEN full of Range  Spoke,
Deceitful Nymph I see thy Art,
And tho' I can't my gift revoke,
I'll disappoint its Nobler Part.

lines.line_text: LET Stubborn Pride Possess thee long,
And be thou Negligent of Fame,
With ev'ry Muse to Grace thy Song,
May'st thou despise a Poets Name.

stanzas.stanza_text:
LET Stubborn Pride Possess thee long,
And be thou Negligent of Fame,
With ev'ry Muse to Grace thy Song,
May'st thou despise a Poets Name.

lines.line_text: OF Modest Poets thou be first,
To silent Shades repeat thy Verse,
Till  and  almost burst,
Yet hardly dare one Line Rehearse.

stanzas.stanza_text:
OF Modest Poets thou be first,
To silent Shades repeat thy Verse,
Till  and  almost burst,
Yet hardly dare one Line Rehearse.

lines.line_text: AND last, my Vengeance to Compleat,
May you Descend to take Renown,
Prevail'd on by the Thing you hate,
A  and one that wears a Gown.

stanzas.stanza_text:
AND last, my Vengeance to Compleat,
May you Descend to take Renown,
Prevail'd on by the Thing you hate,
A  and one that wears a Gown.
